title: Comparative keyword analysis, gender and language: a proposal for the secondary analysis of illness narratives
abstractText: A new method (comparative keyword analysis) will be developed for analysing qualitative interview transcripts and other documentary sources. The project is an interdisciplinary collaboration between sociology and linguistics. The project will deliver both methodological innovations and substantive original findings in the area of gender, illness experience and language. Secondary analysis of a large archive of interviews with people describing their experiences of illness, gathered in association with the Dipex website project (www.dipex.org.uk) is at the core of the project. As well as being of interest to sociologists and linguists in the academy, these findings will contribute to a better understanding of the needs and concerns of people with a variety of illnesses, thus informing clinicians, carers and health information providers. Methodologically the project will deliver a comparative assessment of the features of qualitative interviews and postings in web-based forums, thus evaluating the latter as a research resource. Different types of text analysis software for delivering findings will be assessed, with a particular focus on the effect of ‘built-in’ interpretive schemes, such as word dictionaries.
